metadata.case_name: Prof. Ram Singh & Ors. v. State

facts.text: Petitioners Prof. Ram Singh (President), Bal Raj Khanna (Vice-President), Ram Nath Kalia (Secretary) of Hindu Mahasabha Delhi State arrested on 22nd August 1950 by District Magistrate Delhi under s.3(2) r/w s.3(1)(a)(i) Preventive Detention Act 1950.
Detention order by Rameshwar Dayal, DM Delhi, satisfied necessary for maintenance of public order in Delhi.

Grounds of detention: speeches generally in past and particularly on dates like 13th/15th August 1950 at public meetings in Delhi such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims, prejudicing public order; necessary to detain to prevent such speeches.
Petitioners applied to High Court at Simla under Art 226, petitions dismissed by Khosla and Falshaw JJ.
Petitioners filed petitions under Art 32 in Supreme Court for habeas corpus.
DM affidavit: satisfied from materials by experienced persons that detention necessary to prevent prejudicial acts to public order; denies mala fides.

legal_issues.text: Whether preventive detention under s.3 Preventive Detention Act valid despite abridging freedom of speech under Art 19(1)(a), or whether Art 19 applies as per Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan.
Whether grounds of detention too vague/indefinite, violating Art 22(5) right to make representation, needing gist/offending passages of speeches.
Whether detention orders invalid for not specifying period of detention.
Whether detention mala fide to stifle political opposition.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Act cannot prevent speeches prejudicial to public order as public order not authorized restriction under Art 19(2); detention ultra vires per Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art 19(1)(a), Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras 1950 SCR 594, Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi 1950 SCR 605

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds vague: time/place given but no offending passages/gist; cannot make effective representation per Art 22(5) and Atma Ram.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art 22(5), State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya 1951 SCR 167

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders do not specify detention period, indefinite.
Mala fide: to stifle opposition to Congress policies, unrelated to public order.

respondent_arguments.text: Detention valid per Gopalan; Art 19 not applicable to personal liberty deprivation under Arts 21/22.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras 1950 SCR 88, Arts 19,21,22

respondent_arguments.text: Grounds sufficient: time, place, general effect stated; no need for passages as not prosecution; petitioners can deny/rebut.
Period covered by s.12 max 1 year; not indefinite per Ujager Singh.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act s.12, Ujager Singh v. State of Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: No mala fides; satisfied from materials for public order.

court_reasoning.text: Majority (Sastri J.): Detention governed by Gopalan; Art 19 freedoms distinct from personal liberty under Art 21/22; no conflict with Romesh Thapar etc. as those on direct restrictions, not detention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law depriving personal liberty not tested under Art 19 but Arts 21/22; s.3 valid.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds not vague: time/place/effect given sufficient for representation; no need for passages as not trial, detaining authority's satisfaction; public speeches but regret no record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art 22(5) complied; Atma Ram does not require passages in all speech cases.

court_reasoning.text: Period not needed as s.12 prescribes max 1 year; per Ujager Singh.
No proof of mala fides; mere allegation vs affidavit denial.
Dissent (Mahajan J.): Grounds insufficient; public speeches, no privilege; need substance/words/gist to rebut inference of disaffection, enable effective representation per Art 22(5), Atma Ram.

Dissent (Bose J.): Grounds inadequate; detenu must know words/acts charged; speeches 'verbal acts'; need gist to meet charges effectively, esp no oral hearing; liberal construction for fundamental rights.

holdings.text: Preventive detention under Act valid even if abridges Art 19(1)(a); tested under Arts 21/22 per Gopalan.
Grounds sufficient if enable representation; no mandatory disclosure of speech passages/gist in these facts.
No need to specify period in order due to s.12.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 19 not applicable to detention laws; validity under Arts 21/22

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions on speech under Art 19(2); not applicable to detention

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions on speech/press under Art 19(2); not detention

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds must enable representation; vagueness test; but no broad rule for speech passages

precedents_cited.case_name: Ujager Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: No need for period in order; s.12 sufficient

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: No need for period in order

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights to speech, liberty, detention procedure, writs

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Detention orders, grounds communication, max period

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous to speech offences; charges need substance of words

outcome.summary: Petitions under Art 32 dismissed by majority (Sastri J.); detention valid, grounds sufficient. Dissent by Mahajan J. and Bose J.: grounds vague, order release.

key_quotes.text: "If there is a legislation directly attempting to control a citizens freedom of speech or expression... the question whether that legislation is saved by the relevant saving clause of article 19 will arise. If, however, the legislation is not directly in respect of any of these subjects, but as a result of the operation of other legislation... the question of the application of article 19 does not arise."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Chief Justice in Gopalan distinguishing Art 19 from detention laws

key_quotes.text: "the sufficiency of this second communication of particulars was a justiciable issue, the test being whether it is sufficient to enable the detained person to make a representation which, on being considered, may give relief to the detained person."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Atma Ram on Art 22(5) grounds

key_quotes.text: "Without knowing the substance of the offending passages in the speeches from which the inference has been drawn by the District Magistrate it is possible to prove that this inference is not justified."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "in the case of a speech, the words used are everything. They have been called verbal acts... He cannot know what the authorities think he said unless they give him some reasonable inkling."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bose J. dissent emphasizing need for speech particulars
